poem:
**Press Fleet**

So much depends  
upon  

a windscreen  
boasting biohazard  
proof  

parked at the curb  
of tomorrow—  

the rich  
testing brakes  
against an imagined  
war  

while the motor  
hums cleanly  
in the present,  

and the name  
on the badge  
goes dark.

The year was 2019, and I was test-driving a Tesla; while I was ambling off the forecourt, the PR told me jauntily that the windscreen was made of a material that would protect the driver from biohazards. I hit the brakes. “You what? What kind of biohazard? What model of consumption was this, that the rich used their wealth to prepare for the mayhem their resource-capture would unleash, while the less-rich prepared slightly less well?
